text.p: Canada's embattled Bre-X Minerals Ltd said on Thursday that it received court protection from its creditors and that its chief of exploration John Felderhof resigned at the company's request.

Bre-X said its request for creditor protection was granted by the Alberta Court of Queen's Bench, which also appointed Price Waterhouse Ltd to monitor the assets and records of Bre-X and its sister companies, Bresea Resources Ltd and Bro-X Minerals Ltd.

Bre-X also said that "in response to a request from the companies, John Felderhof has resigned from the Boards of Directors of each of Bre-X, Bro-X and Bresea, and is no longer in their employ effective immediately."
Felderhof is currently at his home in the Cayman Islands.
Bre-X Minerals Chief Executive David Walsh said the purpose of the court filing was two-fold.

"Firstly, with the resignation of two outside directors announced yesterday from the respective boards, we felt it was important that shareholders and creditors of Bre-X, Bresea, and Bro-X derive some confidence from the fact that the assets of the various companies will remain intact," Bre-X Chief Executive David Walsh said in a statement.
Bre-X said on Wednesday that directors Paul Kavanagh and Hugh Lyons quit, leaving three Bre-X managers as the company's remaining directors.
"Secondly, this provides the basis for a mechanism by which the various claims being advanced against the companies can be dealt with in an orderly way," Walsh said.
The Royal Canadian Mounted Police launched an official investigation into the Busang gold scandal on Thursday.
"We're commencing with a preliminary investigation and making some initial inquiries," RCMP spokeswoman Deleen Schoff said by telephone.
Walsh asked the RCMP on Tuesday to investigate an alleged fraud perpetrated against his company, but he did not name a suspect.
A second fraud complaint was filed by the Ontario Securities Commission, one of Canada's securities regulators.
The commission also was investigating Bre-X for possible violations of insider trading and disclosure laws.

Bre-X had touted Busang as the century's richest gold strike until a consultant said on Sunday there was virtually no gold worth mining at the Indonesian mine and called the case a fraud "without precedent in the history of mining."
